APPLIED CATALYSIS A: GENERAL ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 163-183 CO adsorption on supported Pd catalysts studied by adsorption microcalorimetry and temperature programmed desorption Holger Dropsch1, Manfred Baerns* Lehrstuhl fiir Technische Chemie, Ruhr-Universitiit Bochum, D-44780 Bochum, Germany Received 16 June 1996; received in revised form 4 December 1996; accepted 4 December 1996 Abstract The adsorption of CO on silica-, alumina- and titania-supported Pd catalysts (2, 5, and 10 wt% Pd) has been studied by adsorption microcalorimetry and temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiments in a flow system at atmospheric pressure. On supported Pd catalysts, bridge- bonded CO was found to be the dominant CO(ads) species. The observed influence of Pd loading on CO adsorption energetics was explained in terms of particle size and/or surface structure of the Pd crystallites. Support materials can be divided into active (TiO2, A1203) and inert (SiO2) supports, where Pd catalysts with active supports are characterized by (1) an increased sensitivity of CO adsorption to reduction temperature, (2) promotion of CO dissociation, and (3) an increased activity of surface carbon towards hydrogenation, as compared to Pd catalysts supported on inert silica. Keywords: CO adsorbed on silica-, alumina- and titania-supported Pd; TPD of CO from differently supported Pd; Heats of CO adsorption; Linear and bridge-bonded CO(ads) species on supported Pd; Influence of Pd loading and type of support material on adsorption and dissociation of CO; Analysis of surface carbon by TPSR in H2 1. Introduction CO adsorption on noble metals has been the subject of a large number of papers. For instance, the adsorption behaviour of CO on surfaces of Pd single crystals, polycrystalline Pd films, and supported Pd catalysts has been discussed in terms of * Corresponding author. In contrast, there are still very few studies in which the influence of properties and pretreatment conditions of supported Pd catalysts on the Pd-CO adsorption strength have been investigated in detail. Therefore, the aim of the present study was to elucidate the influence of loading and dispersion of Pd, type of support material and the reduction temperature on energetics and mechan- ism of CO adsorption on supported Pd catalysts. For this purpose, a combined approach of adsorption microcalorimetric investigations and temperature pro- grammed desorption (TPD) experiments was chosen to balance the disadvantages of each of the experimental methods. Adsorption microcalorimetry gives precise values for the heats of adsorption but does not allow any insight into the nature of adsorbed species [6-8]. On the other hand, in the case of porous catalysts the calculation of adsorption energies from TPD spectra is complicated by peak shifts due to readsorption and diffusional limitations [9], but desorption experi- ments can give detailed information on nature and number of surface species. To gain detailed insights into the dissociation of CO adsorbed on the catalyst surfaces and the nature of the resulting adsorbed carbon species, the temperature pro- grammed surface reaction (TPSR) technique in a flowing hydrogen atmosphere was applied. 2. Methods of investigation and data evaluation 2.1. Adsorption calorimetric measurements For the performance of adsorption calorimetric measurements as well as TPD experiments within a single apparatus, a differential scanning microcalorimeter of the Tian-Calvet type [6-8] (Setaram DSC 111) was connected to a gas supply system which allowed gas flows of inert carrier gases or reactant gases through both sample and reference cells of the DSC to be precisely adjusted. All experi- ments were performed in this flow system at atmospheric pressure using He (Messer Griesheim, 99.999% pure) as an inert carrier gas which was further purified by passing it through an Oxisorb cartridge (Messer Griesheim) to remove trace impurities of O2 and H20. The catalyst samples were placed in two identical quartz-tube micro fixed-bed reactors (i.d.---7 mm). Both reactors were brought into the heat sensitive zone of the calorimeter. For on-line analysis of the effluent gas immediately downstream from the reactors, a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Micromass PC, VG Quadrupoles) equipped with a heated capillary inlet system was used which was capable of measuring mass spectral intensities for up to 16 preselected masses simultaneously. With this apparatus, measure- ments of heats of adsorption could be performed by injecting defined amounts of the gaseous adsorptive into the carrier gas flow. The amount of heat libe- rated during CO adsorption on the Pd catalyst was then determined from H. Dropsch, M. The calorimetric calibration factor was determined by the manufacturer of the DSC by means of an electrical calibration cell (Joule effect) [6,7] and was verified by comparing the experimentally determined specific heat of melting of indium powder (Janssen, 99.999% pure) with literature data [10]. The amount of CO adsorbed from each pulse was calculated by subtracting the amount of CO which was not adsorbed and left the sample reactor from the known amount of CO introduced into the reactor from the sample loop; the amount of CO leaving the reactor was quantitatively determined by mass spectrometry. Differential heats of adsorption qads were then calculated using [6-8]: qads,i ~ Qi/nads,i (2) with Qi and naas,i being the heat liberated and the amount adsorbed after injection of pulse i. Baerns/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 163-183 2.2. Temperature programmed desorption of CO The principle of TPD and TPSR techniques has been described in detail in numerous reviews, e.g., [14]. For the TPD experiments described in this work, the linear temperature scanning mode of the DSC was used to subject the catalyst samples to a linear temperature schedule after a defined amount of CO has been adsorbed on the catalyst surface at constant temperature. In the course of the linear ramp of catalyst temperature, the rate of desorption rdes, defined by dnads ~ ( Edes) m rdes -- -- kdes,0 exp -- -~--~-fnads (5) increases exponentially. In Eq. (5), m, kdes,0 and Ed~s are the kinetic order, the frequency factor, and the activation energy of desorption, which is equivalent to the heat of adsorption for non-activated adsorption processes [14]. In the case where different adsorbed CO species have significantly different activation energies of desorption Edes, typical TPD spectra are obtained which exhibit distinct peaks for the different CO(ads) species. On the other hand, in most cases of TPD from practical catalysts broad spectra with significant peak overlaps are observed; this is due to similar values of Ed~s as well as readsorption and diffusion effects inside the catalyst bed [9]. From a material balance for the adsorptive in the gas phase and adsorbed on the catalyst surface it can be shown that rdes is proportional to the partial pressure of the adsorptive [14], so that quantitative analysis of the effluent gas from the TPD reactor by MS yields desorption rates in ~tmol/s, or, taking into account the mass of the catalyst bed mcat, specific desorption rates in ~tmol s-1 gcat-1. The latter quantity was preferred in the representation of all TPD spectra obtained in this work. 3. Experimental 3.1. Catalyst preparation and pretreatment SiO2 (Aerosil 200, Degussa), A1203 (aluminium oxide C, Degussa), and TiO2 (titanium dioxide P25, Degussa) with specific surfaces of 200, 100, and 50 m2/g, respectively, were used as support materials. These materials were calcined in air at 873 K for 14 h prior to metal loading. Catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation using a solution of Pd(NO3)2.2H20 in diluted nitric acid. In this manner, catalysts with Pd loadings of 2, 5, and 10 wt% Pd were prepared. After impregnation the catalyst precursors were air-dried at 403 K for 4 h and subse- quently calcined in air at 673 K for 14 h. For the experiments, a sieve fraction with particle diameters between 160 and 250 ~tm was chosen. After introduction into the calorimeter, the catalyst samples (typically 70 mg) were pretreated in situ by heating them to 473 or 773 K in flowing hydrogen (40 ml/min) for 3 h. To H. Dropsch, M. Baerns/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 163-183 167 regenerate catalysts that have already been used in CO adsorption experiments, the samples were oxidized in a flow of 20 ml/min of air at 673 K prior to reduction. Following the reduction step, the catalyst samples were flushed with He (50 ml/ min) at 773 K for 1 h to remove hydrogen and water adsorbed on the catalyst surface. Finally, the samples were cooled down to the adsorption temperature in flowing He. 3.2. Calorimetric measurements All adsorption calorimetric experiments were carded out at Tads=300 K. For determining heats of adsorption, both the sample and the reference cell of the calorimeter were filled with equal amounts of catalyst to balance differential heat flows due to fluctuations in the carder gas flow or in the temperature of the calorimeter jacket. The amount of catalyst in the sample and reference reactors was chosen so that the heat sensitive zone of the calorimeter was completely filled to obtain maximum sensitivity of the DSC. Following the pretreatment of the catalyst sample, the rate of the carrier gas flow was set to 10 ml/min through both the sample and reference reactors. After attainment of thermal equilibrium of the calorimeter, pulses of pure or He-diluted CO (Messer Griesheim, 99.997% pure) were injected into the carder gas flow using a calibrated sample loop (Alltech, 0.1 ml) connected to a GC pulse valve (Valco). The amount of chemisorbed CO and the heats of CO adsorption on the Pd catalysts were determined as described in Section 2 (see Eqs. (1)-(4)). The injection of pulses of the adsorptive was stopped when the heat of adsorption and the fraction adsorbed from each pulse remained constant at low values, because the extra CO adsorbed from these pulses was desorbed subsequently by the flowing carrier gas at 300 K as was evident from the endothermic DSC signal observed simultaneously [15]; this amount of CO could certainly be ascribed to a loosely adsorbed proportion which was not intended to be accounted for. 3.3. Temperature programmed desorption of CO For TPD of CO, only one reactor was filled with the catalyst sample, while the reference cell of the calorimeter contained an empty quartz reactor to allow calibration of the MS by CO pulses after each TPD experiment and, therefore, enable calculation of specific desorption rates rdes from MS intensities. For each catalyst, a sample weight was chosen which resulted in a constant height of the catalyst bed of 8 mm. As was shown by Herz et al. [16], in the case of CO TPD from porous supported platinum metal catalysts into a flowing carrier gas at atmospheric pressure it is impossible to circumvent the broadening and shift of TPD peaks due to readsorption and diffusional limitations. The height of the catalytic bed is one of the factors that determine the extent of peak shift by the above-mentioned effects and can be controlled most easily [9]. After in situ 168 H. Dropsch, M. Baerns/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 163-183 pretreatment, the catalyst sample was cooled down to adsorption temperature (Tars=300 K) in flowing He. CO adsorption was accomplished by injection of CO pulses into the carder gas flow until a specified surface coverage 0(CO) or saturation of the catalyst surface had been obtained. Following the adsorption step, the sample reactor was flushed with He at 300 K for 30 rain in order to obtain a low and stable background for mass 28 by removing gas phase and physisorbed CO. Subsequently, CO TPD was performed by heating the catalyst sample from 300 to 1000 K with a constant heating rate/3 of 20 K/min in a He flow of 50 ml/ min. During the temperature ramp, the mass spectral intensities for masses 2 (H2), 15 (CH4), 18 (H20), 28 (CO), and 44 (CO2) were recorded as a function of catalyst temperature; concerning the origin of these desorption and reaction products see Sections 4 and 5. 3.4. Analysis of surface carbon For the analysis of carbonaceous deposits left on the catalyst surfaces after temperature programmed CO desorption, the catalyst samples were first cooled down to 300 K after completion of the TPD experiments and were subsequently heated up to 1000 K with/3=20 K/min in a flow of 5 ml/min H2+50 ml/min He. During this TPSR between surface carbon C(ads) and H2, the MS intensities for masses 2 (H2), 15 (CH3 from hydrocarbons), 16 (CH4), 27 (C2H3 from C2+- hydrocarbons), 30 (C2H6), 44 (C3H8), and 58 (C4Hlo) were recorded, so that the amount of C(ads) left on the catalyst surface after CO TPD could be calculated from the amount of hydrocarbons formed in the TPSR experiments. The complete removal of C(ads) after TPSR in H2/He was checked by comparing the TPD spectra obtained from CO TPD experiments performed before and after the TPSR runs on the same catalyst sample. 4. Results 4.1. Heats of adsorption and chemisorption capacity of CO The differential heats of CO adsorption on 10 wt% Pd/SiO2, 10 wt% Pd/TiO2, and 10 wt% Pd/A1203 obtained by adsorption microcalorimetry are presented in Figs. 1-3. To show the influence of catalyst pretreatment, each figure exhibits qads(CO) obtained after reduction of the catalyst precursors at 473 or 773 K, respectively. The effect of reduction temperatures is almost negligible for Pd/SiO2; in contrast, a marked influence on CO heats of adsorption and chemisorption capacities is observed in the case of Pd/TiO2 and Pd/A1203. As can be seen form Figs. 1-3, two regions of CO adsorption on the supported Pd catalysts can be distinguished. Discussion In the subsequent discussion, the chemisorptive CO uptakes, the heats of CO adsorption, and the TPD and TPSR spectra obtained by the experimental methods described in Sections 2 and 3 are discussed with respect to the adsorbed CO species, the weight loading and dispersion of Pd, and the influence of the support material and the reduction temperature, respectively. Special attention is given to the dissociation of CO adsorbed on supported Pd catalysts. In the case of the Pd/SiO2, Pd/TiO2 and Pd/AI203 catalysts studied here, diffuse reflectance FTIR (DRIFT) spectroscopic studies have been performed using the same pre- H. Dropsch, M. Baerns /Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 163-183 177 treatment conditions as described above; details of the apparatus and experimental methods are described elsewhere [20]. These infrared spectroscopic results will be used to interpret and support the experimental results obtained in the present work. 5.1. Influence of CO surface coverage, adsorbed CO species From IR spectra [20] recorded after saturating catalyst samples of PdlSiO2, Pd/TiO2, and Pd/A1203 with CO at room temperature and heating it subsequently to higher temperatures the desorption sequence PdCO (linearly adsorbed CO) < Pd2CO (bridge-bonded CO) was found, i.e., PdCO desorbs first because of its lower Pd-CO bonding energy. Roughly, a temperature of 500 K was found to mark the borderline between the desorption of PdCO (Tdes<500 K) and Pd2CO (Tdes>500 K) [20]. From the DRIFT results it can be concluded that CO desorption peaks in the TPD spectra of Pd]SiO2 (Fig. 4), Pd]TiO2 (Fig. 5) and Pd]A1203 (Fig. 6) with peak temperatures TIn(CO)<500 K are related to linearly adsorbed CO, whereas CO peak maximum temperatures that exceed 500 K can be attributed to CO desorption from PdzCO. From this point of view, most of the CO2 formed during the CO TPD experiments can be attributed to CO adsorbed as Pd2CO because PdCO is almost completely desorbed at 500 K as discussed above, whereas CO2 desorption becomes significant only above 500 K. The similarity of the CO2 desorption profiles observed during CO TPD from 10 wt% Pd/AI203 for different initial CO surface coverages also supports the conclusion that bridge- bonded CO, i.e., PdzCO, is the main source of CO2 formation during CO TPD. In addition, CO2 adsorption on the pure oxidic supports at 500 K can be neglected as was confirmed by TPD experiments with CO2 on SiO2, TiO2 and A1203. Therefore, from the analysis of the CO and CO2 desorption spectra presented in Figs. 4-6 it can be concluded that bridge-bonded CO forms the most abundant CO(ads) species on the surface of the supported Pd catalysts studied in this work. This conclusion is in good agreement with LEED studies of CO(ads) on Pd single crystal surfaces [1-3] and with the DRIFT results reported in [20]. Bridge-bonded CO is not only the most abundant and strongest bound CO(ads) species on the surface of Pd/SiO2, Pd/TiO2 and Pd/A1203; from a kinetic point of view, it also represents the first CO(ads) species formed when gaseous CO contacts the surface of supported Pd. This is evident from an inspection of the CO desorption spectra obtained for different initial CO coverages 0o(CO) on 10 wt% Pd/AI203 (Fig. 7). Exposing the catalyst surface to CO doses that correspond to 00(CO)=0.23, 0.41, or 0.61 exclusively leads to the formation of PdzCO when a desorption temperature of 500 K is accepted to mark the border between the desorption of CO from PdCO and PdzCO as discussed above. In agreement with DRIFT results [20], a marked fraction of linear adsorbed CO is only observed when the catalyst sample is exposed to high CO doses so that 0o(CO) exceeds 0.80 (cf. spectra (d) and (e) in Fig. 7). 178 H. Baerns/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 163-183 With increasing initial CO coverage a low temperature shift of the CO desorption peak maxima was observed in Fig. 7 which can be interpreted in terms of repulsive interactions between the permanent dipoles of adsorbed CO molecules [5], indirect interactions of CO(ads) molecules over the electron gas of the Pd crystallites [21], or an intrinsic energetic heterogeneity of the metal surface arising from the existence of surface defects like steps, kinks and corner or edge atoms, respectively [22]. The low temperature shift of the CO desorption peaks is further confirmed by the steadily decreasing differential heats of adsorption observed for increasing CO surface coverage in the energy spectra presented in Figs. 1-3. From the discussion above, the initial heat of CO adsorption on the Pd/SiO2, Pd/TiO2 and Pd/A1203 catalysts (Table 1) can be essentially regarded as the adsorption energy of bridge- bonded CO on the clean catalyst surfaces, whereas qads(CO) values for higher CO surface coverages are presumably influenced by the formation of both PdzCO and PdCO, with the adsorption energy of linear adsorbed CO being of greater influence at higher 0(CO). In the TPD spectra of the supported Pd catalysts studied, three (Pd/AI203, Fig. 5), or four (Pd/SiO2, Fig. 4, and Pd/TiO2, Fig. 6) CO desorption peaks can be identified. In agreement with this observation, multiple peak desorption spectra obtained during CO desorption from Pd supported on support pellets [18,23] or oxide films [22,24-27] have been reported by other authors and were interpreted in terms of PdCO and PdzCO formed on Pd(l 0 0) and Pd(1 1 1) planes [18,23] or CO adsorption on defect sites in contrast to well-ordered crystal faces [22]. Although no safe distinction between the two models can be made from the number of observed CO desorption peaks, a CO desorption on different Pd crystal planes seems more probable because well-defined Pd(1 0 0) and Pd(1 1 1) faces have been identified on the Pd crystallites of 2 wt% Pd/A1203 by electron microscopy [28]. 5.2. Influence of Pd weight loading and dispersion From the microcalorimetric pulse adsorption experiments, an increase of the integral and initial heats of CO adsorption on Pd/SiO2, Pd/TiO2 and Pd/AI203 could be derived on lowering the Pd loading of the catalysts from 10 to 5 wt% and 2 wt% (Table 1). The magnitude of this effect seems to be influenced by the support material according to the series Pd/SiO2<Pd/TiOz<Pd/AI203. On the other hand, there seems to be no direct correlation between Pd loading and Pd dispersion for Pd/SiO2 and Pd/TiO2; moreover, for Pd/AlzO3 an increase of Ded with increasing Pd loading is observed in Table 1. However, for the interpretation of heats of CO adsorption in terms of metal surface structure it must be considered that Dea only represents a measure for the mean Pd crystallite size, so that the establishment of a simple correlation between Opd and qint(CO) or qads,o(CO) might be misleading. Using an adsorption microcalorimetric method, Chou and Vannice [29] observed a marked increase in the integral heats of adsorption when H. Dropsch, M. Baerns/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 163-183 179 CO was adsorbed on small oxide supported Pd crystals if their size fell below a critical diameter of 3 nm. As was shown by a TEM study of Pd/TiO2 catalysts prepared by wet impregnation [30], the fraction of Pd crystallites with diameters <3 nm increased markedly when going from 5 wt% to 2 wt% Pd. Therefore, the increase of heats of CO adsorption observed for decreasing loading of Pd is tentatively assigned to an increased number of small Pd crystallites, which are known to exhibit distinct differences in their electronic properties when compared to larger Pd crystallites or Pd single crystals [31-36]. Alternatively, the surfaces of the catalysts with lower Pd loadings might possess a higher number of surface defects, which are thought to represent adsorption sites with high Pd-CO bonding energy [22]. Considering the quite pronounced increase of heats of CO adsorption for catalysts with lower Pd loading, a marked high temperature shift of the CO desorption peaks with decreasing Pd content of the catalysts should be expected. In contrast, the observed peak shifts are relatively small; in the Pd/A1203 system, the position of the most intense CO peak shifts from 675 K (10 wt% Pd) to 685 K (5 wt% Pd) and finally to 690 K (2 wt% Pd). On the other hand, positions of desorption peaks in CO TPD from supported platinum metals at atmospheric pressure are largely influenced by readsorption and diffusional limitations, as was shown by Herz et al. [16]. Keeping other experimental parameters constant, the influence of these effects increases with increasing adsorption capacity of the catalyst [9,16]. In the case of the catalysts studied here, the peak shift due to an increase of the Pd-CO binding energy can therefore be considered to be partially compensated by a high temperature peak shift caused by readsorption and diffusional limitations, which is more pronounced for catalysts with higher Pd weight loading. With the exception of the Pd/SiO2 system, the shape of the CO and CO2 desorption spectra is not significantly influenced by the Pd weight loading. The relative intensities and, therefore, the relative abundances of different CO(ads) species are similar for PdlTiO2 and Pd/AI203 catalysts with different Pd content. The differences observed for 5 wt% Pd/SiO2 in comparison to Pd/SiO2 catalysts with higher and lower Pd loading are most probably explained by differences in the experimental conditions during catalyst preparation. 5.3. Influence of the support material and reduction temperature For Pd catalysts with a constant loading of 2, 5, or 10 wt% Pd, the irreversible uptake of CO increases according to the sequence Pd/SiO2~Pd/TiO2<Pd/A1203, as can be seen from the results of the adsorption microcalorimetric experiments presented in Table 1. In contrast, the specific surfaces of the catalysts increase according to Pd/TiO2 (~ 15 m2/g)<Pd/A1203 (~70 m2/g)<Pd/SiO2 (~ 160 m2/g) [37], caused by a corresponding increase in the specific surfaces of the pure oxidic supports (TiO2<AI203<SiO2). Impregnation of the low-surface support TiO2 180 H. Dropsch, M. Baerns/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 163-183 should therefore yield catalysts with significantly lower Pd dispersions compared to catalysts obtained by impregnating the high-surface support SiO2 with the same amount of Pd. This is obviously not the case as is evident from the Dpd data presented in Table 1. Based on this observation, a distinction between active (TiO2, A1203) and inert (SiO2) carriers can be made: In the case of active supports, interactions between Pd atoms and the oxide surface are postulated which lead to a enhanced dispersion of the metal on the carrier surface. This assumption is supported by an experimental and theoretical study on a Pd/c~- A1203(1012) model catalyst where XPS and EELS measurements and model calculations revealed an anchoring of single Pd atoms at anionic vacancies of the oxide surface [38]. The strength of interaction seems to be determined by the percent ionic character of the oxide which is correlated to the partial negative charge 6o of the oxide anion. For the carrier oxides studied here, 6o amounts to -0.23 for SiO2, -0.31 for A1203, and -0.39 for TiO2 (calculated using the Sanderson method [39]). For all supported Pd catalysts studied in this work, the irreversible CO chemisorptive uptake ntot(CO) decreased when the reduction temperature of the catalyst precursor was raised from 473 to 773 K (Table 1). Considering the relative loss of adsorption capacity Antot(CO)/ntot(CO) due to high temperature reduction, the sequence Pd/SiOz<Pd/A1203<Pd/TiO2 can be established. In contrast, the influence of TRed on the measured heats of CO adsorption is strongly dependent on the type of support: For Pd/TiO2, an increase of the initial heat of CO adsorption is observed after HTR at 773 K, whereas a small but significant drop of qad~,o(CO) is found in the case of Pd/A1203. For the Pd/SiO2 system, T~ed does not seem to have a marked influence on the heats of CO adsorption (Table 1). These observations are in good agreement with the results of a DRIFT study on the same catalysts where corresponding shifts of the IR bands of adsorbed CO were interpreted in terms of an increase (Pd/TiO2) or decrease (Pd/AI203) of the Pd-CO bonding energy [20]. The observed changes in the CO adsorption properties of Pd/TiO2 and Pd/AI203 catalysts may be explained by electronic interactions between the supported metal and the carrier oxide [40]. Alternatively, in the case of Pd/TiO2 a partial coverage of the Pd surface by partially reduced TiOx moieties was postulated to occur after HTR of the catalyst at 773 K [18]. The presence of TiOx on the Pd surface can be imagined to result in an increase in the average distance of CO(ads) molecules; thus, the observed increase in qad~,o(CO) for Pd/TiO2 could be caused by a lowering of repulsive dipole-dipole interactions between adsorbed CO molecules. A possible change of the adsorption properties of Pd/TiO2 and Pd/A1203 can be ruled out because DRIFT studies [20] and CO TPD experiments (Fig. 8) clearly have shown that the original adsorption properties of the catalyst can be almost completely restored when the catalyst samples are subjected to oxidation at 673 K followed by LTR in H2 at 473 K. This reversibility is an indication of the occurrence of SMSIs [17] after high tempera- ture reduction. H. Dropsch, M. Baerns /Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 163-183 181 5.4. CO dissociation on supported Pd catalysts As was shown in an earlier section, experiments of TPSR of carbonaceous residues left on the catalyst surface at the end of CO TPD experiments led to the following conclusions: (a) CO dissociation during temperature programmed CO desorption is observed for all supported Pd catalysts studied in this work. (b) From a quantitative analysis of CH4 formed during TPSR of C(ads) in flowing H2 in comparison with the amount of CO2 formed during CO TPD it can be stated that CO dissociation is the main cause (Pd/SiO2, Pd/AI203) or the only cause (Pd/TiO2) for CO2 formation in the CO TPD experiments. (c) A sequence of catalytic activities towards CO dissociation can be established (Pd/SiOz<Pd/AlzO3<Pd/TiO2) by comparing the degree of conversion of CO(ads) to CO2(g) according to Eq. (6) as well as the starting temperature of CO2 evolution during CO TPD (cf. Figs. 4-6). The high CO dissociation activity of Pd/TiO2 catalysts can be explained by the formation of a tilted CO(ads) structure (Pd-C=O-..Ti) in which the carbon atom is coordinated to a Pd atom and the CO oxygen is attached to the support, e.g., to an anionic vacancy at the metal/support interface [18]. As was shown by static SIMS experiments [41], such tilted or lying CO(ads) structures can be regarded as direct precursors of CO dissociation. In addition, the presence of the TiO2 support increases the reactivity of adsorbed carbon, as is evident from the peak temperatures of the most intense CH4 peaks in the TPSR spectra shown in Fig. 9. If the assumption holds that C(ads) is an intermediate of CO hydrogenation on supported Pd catalysts, this observation is in excellent agreement with activity sequences reported for Pd catalysts with different supports [11]. 6. Conclusions From the experimental results obtained by CO adsorption microcalorimetry and temperature programmed CO desorption from silica-, alumina-, and titania- supported Pd catalysts, the following conclusions can be drawn: 1. Bridge-bonded CO (PdzCO) was found to be the dominant CO(ads) species on the surface of the supported Pd catalysts under study, i.e., PdzCO is more abundant and more strongly bound than linearly adsorbed CO (PdCO). With increasing CO surface coverage, the differential heat of CO adsorption decreases because of direct or indirect repulsive interactions between adsorbed CO molecules. 2. With decreasing Pd weight loading, an increasing strength of the Pd-CO chemisorption bond is observed which can be explained by 182 H. Dropsch, M. Baerns/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 163-183 an increasing number of small Pd crystallites with significantly different electronic properties; an influence of the Pd weight loading on the surface structure of the Pd crystallites. 3. Support materials can be divided into active (TiO2, AlzO3) and inert (SiO2) supports. Active support materials are characterized by the following proper- ties: Sensitivity of CO adsorption properties to the reduction temperature which is most clearly recognized by the drop of CO adsorption capacity observed after high temperature reduction. Promotion of CO dissociation during temperature programmed CO desorption. Increased activity of surface carbon produced by CO dissociation towards hydrogenation to methane during temperature programmed surface reaction in H2. The different properties of Pd catalysts with active supports can be explained by an activation of the Pd/oxide interface by electronic interactions between metal and support and/or by a partial coverage of Pd crystallites by (sub)oxidic support particles. The strength of interaction between metal and support increases with increasing ionic character (SiO2<A1203<TiO2) of the support oxide. The adsorption of CO on silica-, alumina- and titania-supported Pd catalysts (2, 5, and 10 wt% Pd) has been studied by adsorption microcalorimetry and temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiments in a flow system at atmospheric pressure. On supported Pd catalysts, bridge-bonded CO was found to be the dominant CO(ads) species. The observed influence of Pd loading on CO adsorption energetics was explained in terms of particle size and/or surface structure of the Pd crystallites. Support materials can be divided into active (TiO2, Al2O3) and inert (SiO2) supports, where Pd catalysts with active supports are characterized by (1) an increased sensitivity of CO adsorption to reduction temperature, (2) promotion of CO dissociation, and (3) an increased activity of surface carbon towards hydrogenation, as compared to Pd catalysts supported on inert silica. coredata.dc:description: The adsorption of CO on silica-, alumina- and titania-supported Pd catalysts (2, 5, and 10 wt% Pd) has been studied by adsorption microcalorimetry and temperature programmed desorption (TPD) experiments in a flow system at atmospheric pressure. On supported Pd catalysts, bridge-bonded CO was found to be the dominant CO(ads) species. The observed influence of Pd loading on CO adsorption energetics was explained in terms of particle size and/or surface structure of the Pd crystallites. Support materials can be divided into active (TiO2, Al2O3) and inert (SiO2) supports, where Pd catalysts with active supports are characterized by (1) an increased sensitivity of CO adsorption to reduction temperature, (2) promotion of CO dissociation, and (3) an increased activity of surface carbon towards hydrogenation, as compared to Pd catalysts supported on inert silica.
coredata.dc:title: CO adsorption on supported Pd catalysts studied by adsorption microcalorimetry and temperature programmed desorption
